title: 107_hr2715
content: The Act may be cited as the "Rim of the Valley Corridor Study Act". Key findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that the greater Southern California metropolitan region, the second largest urban concentration in the US, lacks sufficient park and recreation lands per population. This deficiency deprives residents of health benefits and increases the risk of crime. Habitat protection near the Southern California metropolitan region deprives residents of health benefits, reduced crime, lower social tension, and increased educational opportunities. The Rim of the Valley Corridor provides important assets to the region deserving of increased protection. The Rim of the Valley Corridor surrounding the San Fernando and La Crescenta valleys offers significant scenic, environmental, recreational, educational, scientific, and economic assets to Southern California. It contains endangered Mediterranean chaparral ecosystems and should receive increased protection for public benefit in the future. The Rim of the Valley Corridor, including various mountain ranges and forests, contains endangered Mediterranean chaparral ecosystems and ecotones. The San Gabriel Mountains within the Angeles National Forest are managed for watershed, recreational, and habitat values, not for commercial exploitation. Privately owned lands in the corridor are crucial for scenic and environmental purposes. The Angeles National Forest is managed for watershed, recreational, and habitat values, not for commercial exploitation. Privately owned lands in the Rim of the Valley Corridor are important for scenic, environmental, and recreational purposes and should be protected through voluntary incentives. The State of California has adopted the Rim of the Valley Master Plan to preserve the area's natural and recreational resources. The State of California has adopted the Rim of the Valley Master Plan to protect natural and recreational resources in the area, but lacks financial resources, technical assistance, and expertise from the Federal Government. The Rim of the Valley Master Plan in California aims to protect natural and recreational resources, seeking support from the Federal Government for financial resources and expertise. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a special resource study of the Rim of the Valley Corridor in Southern California to evaluate its national significance and feasibility of becoming part of the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area. The study will follow criteria for potential inclusion in the National Park System. The Secretary will use criteria for studying areas for potential inclusion in the National Park System. Regular consultation with the Rim of the Valley Corridor and Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area Advisory Committee is required. Establishment of Advisory Committee. The Rim of the Valley Corridor and Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area Advisory Committee is established to advise the Secretary of the Interior on a study and recommend boundaries for a new recreation area that reflects the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area. The Committee will recommend boundaries for the new Valley National Recreation Area, reflecting the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area and including the Rim of the Valley Corridor lands and interests. The recommendation must be submitted to the Secretary of the Interior within 365 days of the Committee's first meeting. The Committee, pursuant to Division 23 of the California Public Resources Code, consists of 24 members appointed by the Secretary of the Interior. They are tasked with submitting a recommendation, including maps depicting proposed boundaries for a Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area, within 365 days of the first meeting. Public participation in and comment on the recommendation is also required. The Committee, consisting of 24 members appointed by the Secretary of the Interior, provides opportunities for public participation and comment on the recommendation of boundaries for the Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area. Members include representatives of local governments in the vicinity of the recreation area. The local governments involved in the recommendation of boundaries for the Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area include the city councils of Ventura, Thousand Oaks, Agoura Hills, Westlake Village, Malibu, Calabasas, Burbank, Glendale, La Canada-Flintridge, Pasadena, Sierra Madre, South Pasadena, and Santa Clarita. The city councils of La Canada-Flintridge, Pasadena, Sierra Madre, South Pasadena, Santa Clarita, Moorpark, and the board of supervisors of Los Angeles county, along with other local government representatives, are designated to represent the unincorporated communities within the East Rim of the Valley Trail Corridor. Additionally, the Superintendent of the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area and the Supervisor of the Angeles National Forest are included in the decision-making process. The stakeholders involved in the decision-making process for the East Rim of the Valley Trail Corridor include representatives from the Town Council of Altadena, Crescenta Valley Town Council, Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area, Angeles National Forest, California Department of Parks and Recreation, Santa Monica Mountains Conservancy, Rancho Simi Recreation and Park District, and Conejo Recreation and Park District. The Committee for the East Rim of the Valley Trail Corridor includes representatives nominated by various park districts, with a chairperson and vice chairperson selected from among its members. Members serve without compensation but are reimbursed for expenses. Thirteen members constitute a quorum for conducting business. The Committee for the East Rim of the Valley Trail Corridor consists of members selected by park districts, with a chairperson and vice chairperson chosen from among them. Members serve without pay but are reimbursed for expenses. A quorum is established with 13 members present for conducting business. The Committee will end when the Secretary submits the special resources study to Congress.
